stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on 3D modeling and layout for an ice castle level in Blender. Key activities included refactoring the game's mirror system to be more flexible, implementing a per-level memory allocation system to fix a collision bug, and diagnosing (but not solving) a persistent lighting issue. He also discussed his project release strategy and shared a story about a recent phishing attempt.

development_findings.summary: Kaze encountered a crash due to exceeding the memory limit for collision surfaces in a complex area. He solved it by modifying his custom memory allocator to support per-level memory limits, giving more resources to demanding levels.
development_findings.quote: The problem here is that because the triangles are so big... there need to be a lot of pool nodes... I might have to change the allocation per level because this is unplayable.

development_findings.summary: Kaze completely refactored the hardcoded mirror functionality into a flexible, data-driven system using a custom struct. This new system allows him to easily define a mirror's axis and boundaries, simplifying future level design.
development_findings.quote: Dude, this is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

development_findings.summary: The project's performance is bottlenecked by the Reality Signal Processor (RSP), not the renderer (RDP). This discovery led to the decision to move to F3DEX3, which offers significant RSP performance improvements.
development_findings.quote: We found out that the bottleneck is actually the RSP and not the RDP... that's the entire reason my course one was like stuck at 46 fps.

development_findings.summary: The game is incompatible with the popular SM64 PC Port due to its reliance on custom F3DEX2 features (combiners) that the port does not support.
development_findings.quote: The PC port doesn't support any of the special combiners I do. So on the PC port you will not be able to play this game, unless someone does a lot of work into fixing it.

development_findings.summary: A persistent and difficult bug exists in the emulator-specific ('x2') build where the presence of a second light source incorrectly causes the ambient lighting on Mario to turn off.
development_findings.quote: Something with the shading is really broken right now. I'm still trying to figure out why... The ambient seems to completely disappear.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is designing levels using a 'room' system to aggressively cull unseen geometry, with the goal of achieving a consistent 60 FPS on final hardware.
development_findings.quote: The entire castle is either gonna run 60 fps in the end, I'm pretty sure.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that competent programmers shouldn't be dogmatic about programming languages, as most are functionally similar for general tasks. He views language tribalism as a sign of a 'skill issue'.
context_findings.quote: If you care at all, like even just a little bit about which programming language you use, that is a very strong indicator that you're a terrible programmer. So if anyone tells you to use Rust, just answer skill issue.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is trying to stream and work more on the project to earn more money to support his new child, but struggles with time management due to also having a full-time job.
context_findings.quote: I have a child now and I need more money. So hopefully there will be more streams, but I don't know how I'm going to manage the time wise since I do have a full-time job on top of being all of this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recounted a recent, sophisticated phishing attempt by a fake advertiser. His strict personal security policy prevented him from installing malware, and he collaborated with an anti-scam professional to investigate the attackers.
context_findings.quote: I'm not downloading and running an exe file ever no matter how legit this looks.

context_findings.summary: To avoid legal action from Nintendo, Kaze's release strategy is to distribute a patch file rather than a full ROM. He acknowledges that this will likely lead to unauthorized physical cartridges being sold on sites like Etsy.
context_findings.quote: I will release a patch that will contain only my own changes. And then you will be able to patch this patch onto an N64 ROM... but that is not officially encouraged.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans a multi-stage release: v1.0 and v1.1 will support emulators, but later versions may drop this support to implement N64-specific optimizations (like tri-strips) that current emulators cannot handle, aiming for the best possible performance on original hardware.
context_findings.quote: I will ditch emulator support entirely... Because supporting emulators makes the entire game run slower.

biobak.summary: Kaze adjusted the dimensions of a room to be perfect squares, implying Biobak has high standards for geometric precision and visual quality.
biobak.quote: Fix it now while you can. Before the wrath of Biobak murders me.

biobak.summary: Kaze feels a responsibility to meet a certain level of quality in his 3D modeling and layout work before handing it over to Biobak for his graphics work.
biobak.quote: Really, it's just kind of getting these rooms to look a little nicer. So it's not insulting to Biobak when I pass this over.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present at the beginning of the stream. Kaze made personal, lighthearted comments involving her, such as joking about working to support his wife and imaginary children.

key_stories.title: The Flexible Mirror System Refactor
key_stories.summary: Kaze became frustrated with the rigid, hardcoded mirror system. He decided to refactor it entirely, creating a new data-driven system that allows him to easily add and configure mirrors anywhere in the game by simply defining their properties in a struct.
key_stories.challenge: The in-game mirror system was hardcoded and inflexible, making it difficult to create new mirrors with different properties for new level areas.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the limitations of the old system. He designed a new C struct to hold all mirror parameters. He then rewrote the logic to interpret this struct, tested it, discovered a bug in the player's reflected yaw, and corrected the code to fix it.
key_stories.outcome: A new, flexible mirror system was created that is data-driven. This allows Kaze to define mirror properties (axis, position, range) via a simple struct in the code, greatly simplifying the process of adding mirrors and making the system scalable for the rest of the game.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, this is gonna be the easiest system to add new murals ever.

key_stories.title: The Near-Miss Phishing Scam
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed a sophisticated phishing attempt where scammers impersonated an advertiser to trick him into running malware. His strict security policy and quick thinking not only protected him but also turned the tables, as he ended up providing intelligence to an anti-scam professional.
key_stories.challenge: A very convincing scammer, posing as an advertiser, tried to get Kaze to download and run a malicious executable file under the guise of a special video conferencing app.
key_stories.process: The scammer sent an email that seemed legitimate, referencing Kaze's videos. When they requested a call using a custom app, Kaze refused to download the .exe file. The scammers then provided a suspicious Zoom link, confirming Kaze's suspicions. He investigated their fake GitHub link and contacted the legitimate owner.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze avoided the scam and did not compromise his system. He then contacted the real person whose identity was stolen, who happened to work for an anti-scam software company, and provided them with information to help track the scammers.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm not downloading and running an exe file ever no matter how legit this looks.

key_stories.title: Solving Collision with Per-Level Memory
key_stories.summary: A complex level kept crashing due to memory limits on collision data. Instead of a simple fix, Kaze modified his engine's custom memory allocator to support variable allocations on a per-level basis, creating a sophisticated solution that benefits the entire project.
key_stories.challenge: The game was unplayable in a new, complex area because it was exceeding the global memory allocation for collision surfaces.
key_stories.process: Kaze first diagnosed the problem as insufficient memory for the surface pool. He reasoned that a global increase was inefficient. He then dove into his custom memory allocator code and added logic to check the current level ID and assign a larger memory pool if it matched a level on his new 'exception list'.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a system for per-level memory allocation. This allows him to give more resources to specific, complex levels as needed without wasting memory on simpler ones, solving the crash and making the system more robust for future levels.
key_stories.key_quote: I might have to change the allocation per level because this is unplayable.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions the critical importance of moving to F3DEX3 ('x3') for performance, crediting a collaborator named Sauraen for their work on it. He states the team discovered the RSP, not the RDP, was the main performance bottleneck.
